stories.title: Folk methods of hemorrhoids remedies, quick and radical cure for hemorrhoids

stories.text:
I know that you can already donate extra CPU cycles to computational projects like Folding@Home.

I am wondering how feasible it would be to create a Proof of Work system that verifies a blockchain where the number crunching ends goes towards a useful but difficult computational task (in addition to the innate utility that regular Proof of Work brings).

I think some people who first hear about Proof of Work assume it's Proof of Useful Work (PoUW), at least I did. However I'm not savvy enough to tell the real PoUW projects from the scams. Does anyone know whether the idea is possible on principle, and if there are any existing implementations of the general idea?

Thoughts on whether this type of arrangement would even work as the basis of a store of value are appreciated as well.

Thank you.

Edit: I just found a previous discussion on the same topic: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=27224415.
stories.title: Ask HN: Is a blockchain with Proof of “Useful” Work possible?

stories.text:
Supply chains are still struggling from Covid, China lock downs, war, shipping rate increases, port backlogs, no fab capacity, etc. Component lead times are long, if not impossible to get.

How are you adapting your products so that you can still get to market?
stories.title: Ask HN: How are you adapting hardware/product design to a world with shortages?
A long and specific dni (for fun)
